title: Partner Event | Inspired Generosity: Chicago Sacred Initiative
description: <p>Join us as <strong>Rebekah Coffman</strong>, CHM Curator of Religion and Community History, and <strong>Romana Manzoor</strong>, Executive Vice President for Accreditation, Institutional Effectiveness, & Development for American Islamic College, discuss their collaborative work through CHM\'s Chicago Sacred Initiative and AIC\'s Hassan Institute for Interfaith Encounter.</p>\n

title: SOLD OUT! Member Event | Glessner House Reception
description: <p>CHM members are invited to travel back in time to Victorian-era Chicago through the rich history, art, and revolutionary architecture of the John J. Glessner House. The evening includes tours of select areas led by Glessner House executive director & curator <strong>William Tyre</strong>.</p>\n

title: Film Screening and Discussion | “Walls of Respect: Norman Parish and the Parish Art Gallery”
description: <p>Join us for a screening of <em>Walls of Respect: Norman Parish and the Parish Art Gallery</em>, followed by a discussion with <strong>Norman Parish III</strong>, a son of the artist, art appraiser <strong>Diane Dinkins-Carr</strong>, and artist <strong>Richmond Jones</strong>, whose work was shown in Parish Gallery and who appears in the documentary.</p>\n

title: Walking Tour | Paseo Boricua and Humboldt Park
description: <p>Join professional guide and local resident <strong>Eduardo Arocho</strong> on a walk through Humboldt Park.</p>\n

title: OUT at CHM Walking Tour | North Side LGBTQIA+ Stories
description: <p>Led by <b>Mike McMains</b> of Tours with Mike, this tour explores the businesses and organizations in the Northalsted (formerly Boystown) area in Lakeview. </p>\n

title: Walking Tour | Historic Old Town
description: <p>Join CHM volunteer <strong>Carol Fitzgibbons</strong> to explore stories of recovery from the 1871 Great Chicago Fire and when Old Town was the center of Chicago bohemianism in the 1960s and ’70s.</p>\n

title: OUT at CHM | Downtown LGBTQIA+ Stories Walking Tour
description: <p>Join guide <strong>Mike McMains</strong> of Tours with Mike to discover Chicago’s hidden LGBTQIA+ stories from the 19th century to today while exploring the city’s downtown area. </p>\n

title: Walking Tour | Glitterati on the Gold Coast
description: <p>Join a CHM History Buff volunteer guide and whisk away to a time when Chicago’s rich and famous caroused on the coast.</p>\n

title: Bus Tour | North by Northwest: Infamous Places in the Land Approaching O’Hare
description: <p>Delve into Chicago’s crime history with <b>Richard Lindberg</b>, author of the best-selling Return to the Scene of the Crime: A Guide to Infamous Places in Chicago (1999) and 19 other books. </p>\n

title: Walking Tour | Hyde Park Murals
description: <p>Join artist and educator <b>Juarez Hawkins</b> for a lively historical tour of the murals along the Metra underpasses linking Hyde Park Boulevard and Cornell Avenue in Hyde Park, one of the city’s most engaging neighborhoods. </p>\n

title: Walking Tour | Sheffield Stroll
description: <p>Join CHM History Buff volunteer guide <b>Dave Gudewicz</b> to explore the history of the Sheffield/DePaul neighborhood.</p>\n

title: Virtual Urban History Seminar | “Home Work: Gender, Child Labor, and Education in Urban America, 1870–1930″
description: <p><strong>Ruby Oram</strong> of Texas State University presents “Home Work: Gender, Child Labor, and Education in Urban America, 1870–1930.”</p>\n

title: Creatures of the Night series
description: <p>Creatures of the Night is back this October! Join us every Wednesday in October as we get up close and personal with the natural world with activities and crafts for all ages. our featured animal experts bring in animals for kids and families to meet and learn about while our nature education teachers provide activities […]</p>\n

description: <p>Unwind midweek with a relaxing evening of creativity and nature! </p>\n

title: Wednesday Wind Down with Greening Demos
description: <p>Find some midweek grounding by learning a little more about gardening and growing at Garfield Park Conservatory!</p>\n

description: <p>Join us for a hands-on beekeeping class for all skill levels!</p>\n

title: FLEUROTICA 2025
description: <p>  FLEUROTICA returns Thursday, October 16, 2025 FLEUROTICA spotlights the unique talents of Chicago’s leading floral designers, fashion designers, students and landscape artists as they create breathtaking garments made entirely from plants, flowers and natural materials. All proceeds from FLEUROTICA benefit the Garfield Park Conservatory Alliance’s nature education programs and community resources at the Garfield […]</p>\n

title: 2025 Fall Forum on Teaching and Learning
location: DePaul University - Lincoln Park Student Center
description: Keynote Address by Dr. Kevin Gannon, ”Humanizing Teaching"

title: Ear Taxi Festival presents: The Lost Birds, featuring DePaul Ensemble 20+ and the William Ferris Chorale
description: A stunning choral-orchestral elegy by Christopher Tin, The Lost Birds honors extinct species and the fragile beauty of nature. Featuring William Ferris Chorale and DePaul Ensemble 20+, this concert blends musical storytelling with environmental reflection—perfect for educators, composers, and all who believe in music's power to move and inspire. For more information on this concert, visit the Ear Taxi website.
price: $50 Tier 1; $35 Tier 2; $20 Tier 3; $10 Student (w/valid ID). Additional processing fees apply.

title: Marketing and Sales Career Fair
description: Come join us for an evening of networking and professional development! Students are invited to attend the Fall Career Fair to meet marketing industry professionals from companies represented across the Chicagoland area, expanding their professional network and learning about opportunities available to them during and after their time at DePaul. This event will take place from 3:30-5:30 PM in the DePaul Center 11th floor

title: Climate Action Town Hall (Loop)
description: Learn and discuss DePaul's efforts to develop a plan to address and limit our impact on Climate Change as an institution. Share and collaborate how can you and/or your department/organization can help create a sustainable DePaul. Be sure to register on DeHub to stay connected on any updates! https://cglink.me/2cC/r396500 Refreshments will be provided! This event will be hosted in-person.

title: DePaul GROW® Manager Training
description: Join DePaul GROW®! GROW® (Guided Reflection on Work) is an initiative through the Office of Student Employment, which prepares managers for elevating their management skills and the student employment experience. The intention of GROW® is to make student employment a High-Impact Practice, and to help students' learning across contexts: academics, work, and career goals. This one-time training session prepares managers with the specifics to facilitate GROW® conversations with their student employees. This training will be held in the Loop Career Center conference room, DePaul Center 9500. Lunch will be provided! Sign up for a GROW training session here! Learn more about GROW at the September MSN Session!

title: October 2025 Faculty Council Meeting
description: Monthly meeting of the Faculty Council

title: Language Game Night
description: Do you like languages? Do you like games? Come play some language-related games and connect with other students interested in language and linguistics!

title: Scriptwriting Society
description: Facilitated by the Writing Center, the Scriptwriting Society is a group for writers to share plays, screenplays, or any scripts in a supportive workshop setting with fellow script writers.

title: CLE - Tech Law Boot Camp 2025: Matching Value with IP Strategy
description: Part of the Technology & Data Protection Initiative, CIPLIT’s Tech Law Boot Camp series features lectures by professors, practicing attorneys and other tech specialists on relevant substantive technology topics, including technology management, data privacy, cybersecurity, and Internet law. These lectures are open to DePaul law students, alumni and the Chicago legal community. All events will run from 12:00-1:00 pm in person and over Zoom (RSVP for the link). The first session will be "Matching Value with IP Strategy", hosted by Glen Belvis of Belvis Law, LLC, in Lewis 803. 1 hour CLE will be provided for all requesting attendees. Lunch will be provided for in person attendees. This event is free to attend. RSVP to bdavinge@depaul.edu with how you plan to attend and your ARDC #, if applicable. ---- Full Schedule Session 1 - October 9, 2025: Matching Value with IP Strategy - Glen Belvis, Belvis Law, LLC - Lewis 803Session 2 - October 21, 2025: Introduction to Internet Law - Michael Grynberg, DePaul Law - Lewis 803Session 3 - November 4, 2025: Introduction to Data Privacy - Stephanie Ritter, The Trade Desk

title: Crevices and Crutches Laid Bare: Global Governments and Civil Society Responses to Migrant Housing
location: Richard M. and Maggie C. Daley Building
description: Join us for a thought-provoking talk led by Solutions Lab Grantee Professor Ramya Ramanath, who will explore how irregular migrants navigate housing in global cities such as Santiago, Montevideo, Chicago, Glasgow, and Pretoria. Drawing on case studies, Professor Ramanath will examine how exclusionary government policies intersect with local practices of care and support. The presentation will highlight both barriers to shelter and inspiring examples of inclusive initiatives, while underscoring the urgent need to rethink housing rights, address systemic discrimination, and center migrant voices in shaping equitable policies. Prof. Ramanath with also be joined by Julia Wagner representing the Institute of Global Homelessness. Light snacks will be provided.

title: CSH Excellence in Research Awards Colloquium
description: We are excited to present the 2025 CSH Research Award Colloquium for our Mid-Career Excellence in Research Award recipient, Kashica Webber-Ritchey, Associate Professor of Nursing, and our Excellence in Research Award recipient Deacon Joseph R. Ferrari, Professor and St. Vincent de Paul Professor of Psychology. Please join us for this exciting presentation on their research! **RSVP by October 3rd for in-person attendance - lunch will be served!** “Charting the Path to Research Excellence: My Mid-Career Journey” Kashica Webber-Ritchey Dr. Webber-Ritchey offers a reflective overview of the personal motivations and experiences that have shaped her research career, culminating in the 2025 CSH Mid-Career Excellence in Research Award. She will highlight her current research initiatives, discuss key milestones, and share future directions aimed at advancing health equity and scientific impact. “At Last, My CSH Talk on Procrastination” Dn. Joseph R. Ferrari “Technology makes it easy to delay.... My life is too busy to get things done ... I work best under time pressure." Are these the reasons you use to not begin or complete a task? Did you know 20% of women and men who actively avoid tasks are chronic procrastinators? In this talk, Dn. Joe Ferrari will share insights from decades of research and expertise on chronic procrastination, on which he has published 4 books and over 100 scholarly articles exploring its causes and consequences. This address is open to the entire DePaul community.
